articles.headline: Fed Stands Pat and Says It Is Still Ready to Buy Debt
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve board left open the possibility of buying government debt if there is no improvement in the unemployment rate.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve board left open the possibility of buying government debt if there is no improvement in the unemployment rate.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Officials at the Federal Reserve signaled on Tuesday for the first time that they were worried that the slow-moving economic recovery could be undermined by very low rates of inflation, and hinted strongly that it might resume buying vast amounts of government debt to spur the recovery. While the central bank’s Federal Open Market Committee did not take any new steps on interest rates, it communicated in unmistakable terms its concerns about the fragility of the economic recovery and a threat to stable prices.

articles.headline: The Long View of China’s Currency
articles.snippet: A stronger renminbi would not be a quick fix for our problems, but it is crucial to correcting the global economy’s imbalances.
articles.abstract: A stronger renminbi would not be a quick fix for our problems, but it is crucial to correcting the global economy’s imbalances.

articles.headline: Move to End ‘Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell’ Stalls in Senate
articles.snippet: The Senate voted not to proceed with debate of the annual authorization of military spending that included a provision allowing the repeal of the policy on gay soldiers.
articles.abstract: The Senate voted not to proceed with debate of the annual authorization of military spending that included a provision allowing the repeal of the policy on gay soldiers.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Senate on Tuesday voted against taking up a major military bill that would allow the repeal of the “don’t ask, don’t tell” policy, disappointing advocates of allowing gay Americans to serve openly in the armed forces but leaving open the likelihood of another vote later this year.

articles.headline: Obama’s Economics Chief Is Set to Leave
articles.snippet: The departure of Lawrence H. Summers, the top White House economic adviser, allows President Obama to reshape his economics team after the midterm elections, when Republicans are expected to gain strength.
articles.abstract: The departure of Lawrence H. Summers, the top White House economic adviser, allows President Obama to reshape his economics team after the midterm elections, when Republicans are expected to gain strength.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The White House said Tuesday that Lawrence H. Summers, the chief architect of President Obama’s economic policy, would leave at the end of the year, continuing an exodus of top-level advisers at a time when voters are expressing deep dissatisfaction with the president’s stewardship of the economy.

articles.headline: Stores Scramble to Accommodate Budget Shoppers
articles.snippet: Dollar stores, embracing strategies they learned during the recession, have seen a spike in business.
articles.abstract: Dollar stores, embracing strategies they learned during the recession, have seen a spike in business.
articles.lead_paragraph: The country’s continued economic doldrums have stores scrambling for the once-ignored low-end customer, as people make fewer costly shopping trips to stock their pantries, and increasingly, can only afford inexpensive items in small quantities like those sold at dollar stores.

articles.headline: Step Right Up for Pest Control at Bedbug Meeting
articles.snippet: More than 360 people, with quite a few inventors among them, gathered in Illinois for a conference about the pests.
articles.abstract: More than 360 people, with quite a few inventors among them, gathered in Illinois for a conference about the pests.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROSEMONT, Ill.  This may be the only place in the country where, for two days at least, the prospect of a bedbug infestation carries not the slightest, slimmest of stigmas.

articles.headline: Oracle Growth Plans Worry Rivals and Customers
articles.snippet: A string of acquisitions peaking with the purchase of Sun Microsystems puts Oracle in a position to control more of businesses’ technology purchases.
articles.abstract: A string of acquisitions peaking with the purchase of Sun Microsystems puts Oracle in a position to control more of businesses’ technology purchases.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  Each year, Oracle’s presence looms over this city for a week, during the company’s Open World customer conference. About 41,000 people arrived this week to discuss business software in fine detail and talk over beers. Stretches of downtown streets closed and gave way to makeshift tents housing coffee stands, bars, Lego play areas and candy buffets.

articles.headline: An Iowa Egg Farmer and a History of Salmonella
articles.snippet: Farms tied to one of the country’s biggest egg producers were a source of salmonella in the 1980s and recently.
articles.abstract: Farms tied to one of the country’s biggest egg producers were a source of salmonella in the 1980s and recently.
articles.lead_paragraph: On a July night in 1987, scores of elderly and chronically ill patients at Bird S. Coler Memorial Hospital in New York City began to fall violently sick with food poisoning from eggs tainted with salmonella.

articles.headline: For a Few, Papers Seem a Timely Bet
articles.snippet: A low-profile hedge fund investor has an interest in owning Philadelphia’s two main newspapers.
articles.abstract: A low-profile hedge fund investor has an interest in owning Philadelphia’s two main newspapers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Randall D. Smith, a pioneer in the hard knocks business of vulture investing, is circling a new target: the beleaguered newspaper industry.

articles.headline: Google Campaign to Build Up Its Display Ads
articles.snippet: The company’s interactive billboard going up Wednesday in Times Square has a message for both Madison Avenue and Wall Street: Google has a business beyond search ads.
articles.abstract: The company’s interactive billboard going up Wednesday in Times Square has a message for both Madison Avenue and Wall Street: Google has a business beyond search ads.
articles.lead_paragraph: Google, the online search ad giant that rarely advertises, has decided it needs to advertise the fact that it is in the online display advertising business.
